author: By Mark Landler and Adam Rasgon
title: Back-to-Back Israeli Strikes Show Tragic Gaps in Choosing Targets
description: In an airstrike on Monday in Damascus, Israel’s military displayed pinpoint precision. Hours later in Gaza, that same military killed seven aid workers.
content: About 5 p.m. on Monday, Israeli warplanes streaked across the Syrian border, striking an embassy building in Damascus and killing a cadre of senior Iranian military commanders with the kind of pinpoint accuracy that has earned Israel’s military fear and respect across the Middle East.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Don’t Let Our Broken Politics Mangle Our Faith

content: In 2007, I had a conversation about the culture war with the evangelical pastor Tim Keller that I’ve never forgotten. Keller, who was the founder of Redeemer Presbyterian Church in Manhattan, died last year, a devastating loss.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What to See in N.Y.C. Galleries in April
description: Travis Diehl covers Marian Zazeela’s abstract calligraphy, Christopher Baliwas’s “Skin 2 Skin” show and Luigi Zuccheri’s surreal pastoral scenes.

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Ford Slows Its Push Into Electric Vehicles
description: The automaker said it would delay new battery-powered models and shift its focus to hybrid cars, sales of which are rising fast.
content: Ford Motor on Thursday delayed the production of at least two new electric cars and said it would pivot to making more hybrids. Its decision was the latest sign that large automakers have been forced to rethink their strategy for electric vehicles because sales for those models are slowing.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Georgia Judge Rejects Effort to Dismiss Trump Case on Free Speech Grounds
description: The defense had argued that some of the charges were based on statements Donald Trump and his co-defendants made in 2020 that were constitutionally protected.
content: A judge in Atlanta on Thursday rejected an effort by former President Donald J. Trump and his co-defendants to have the Georgia criminal case against them dismissed on grounds that it was based on comments that were protected by the First Amendment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: N.Y.P.D. Often Ignores Parking-Permit Abuse, Report Says
description: Failing to ticket illegally parked cars with officially issued permits is “a form of corruption that erodes the public trust,” the Department of Investigation said.
content: The New York Police Department routinely fails to ticket illegally parked cars that have city-issued parking permits, especially near precinct houses, and residents’ complaints about permit abuse rarely result in summonses, according to a report issued on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Late Night Rebuts Trump’s Call for ‘Christian Visibility Day’
description: “This is America, buddy. Every day is ‘Christian Visibility Day,’” Desi Lydic said on Wednesday’s “Daily Show.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: A Tribute to the Jazz Great Max Roach Meets His Standards
description: Ayodele Casel leads a program celebrating Roach’s centenary that also includes works by Rennie Harris as well as by Ronald K. Brown and Arcell Cabuag.
content: Nothing dates like technology. The video effects in the Kit Fitzgerald film that opens “Max Roach 100” at the Joyce Theater — a centenary celebration of the great drummer, composer and activist — are clearly from the 1980s. (Remember Max Headroom?) The performances of Roach that the film preserves, however, are timeless.
source.name: The New York Times

title: New York Attorney General Questions Trump’s $175 Million Bond Deal
description: Letitia James said in court papers that the California company providing the guarantee was not qualified to do such deals in New York.
content: The New York attorney general’s office on Thursday took exception to a $175 million bond that Donald J. Trump recently posted in his civil fraud case, questioning the qualifications of the California company that provided it.

content: If you’re 50 or older and reading this article, chances are you are wearing a pair of inexpensive reading glasses to correct your presbyopia, or farsightedness, the age-related decline in vision that makes it progressively more difficult to see fine print and tiny objects.

content: In a scene from the 1997 romantic comedy “Love Jones,” a young poet named Darius recounts to his friend over a game of pool how his first date went with Nina, a beautiful photographer he recently met. They ended up having sex that night, and the next morning, he got up and made breakfast.
source.name: The New York Times

title: They Want to Become Nuns and Priests. Student Debt Holds Them Back.
description: For young adults who want to join certain religious orders, paying off debt before taking a vow of poverty can prove challenging. But their communities are willing to help.
content: It wasn’t until after college that Kendra Baker began to consider becoming a nun. She had been raised a Roman Catholic, and after her father fell from the roof of their home, suffering life-threatening injuries, her family called a priest to come and pray with them. A few hours later, her father opened his eyes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan
title: Lawmaker Is Left With ‘Lifetime Trauma’ as Attacker Pleads Guilty
description: Andrey Desmond pleaded guilty to three felony charges this week in the attack on Maryam Khan, a member of the Connecticut House of Representatives, last June.
content: It has been nearly 10 months since a man attacked Maryam Khan, the first Muslim elected to the Connecticut House of Representatives, outside an Eid al-Adha prayer service in Hartford, Conn. She is still struggling to heal, she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘The Beast’ Review: Master of Puppets
description: Bertrand Bonello’s latest film, starring Léa Seydoux and George MacKay as lovers in three different eras, is an audacious sci-fi romance.
content: Bertrand Bonello’s “The Beast” is an audacious interdimensional romance, techno-thriller and Los Angeles noir rolled up in one. This shamelessly ambitious epic is about, among other things, civilizational collapse and existential retribution, yet it is held together by something delicate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi and Leily Nikounazar
title: Iran Says 17-Hour Battle With Separatists Leaves 28 Dead in 2 Cities
description: Jaish al-Adl, an ethnic Baluch group designated by the United States as a terrorist organization, claimed responsibility for the attacks.
content: Iranian security forces battled simultaneous terrorist attacks by a militant separatist group in a southeast province that raged for nearly 17 hours, with intense gunfights in the streets of two cities that resulted in the deaths of 10 security officers and 18 militants, according to the Ministry of Interior on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Anxiety, Bedtime and Mating: How Animals May React to the Eclipse
description: When the total solar eclipse happens on Monday, animals at homes, farms and zoos may act strangely. Researchers can’t wait to see what happens when day quickly turns to night.
content: While millions of people are preparing to watch the total solar eclipse that will make its way across North America on Monday, the animals in that affected area — in homes, on farms, in zoos and in the wild — missed the news that the moon will block the sun, briefly turning day into night.

content: As the clock struck noon on Thursday, the doors to dozens of polling stations across Kuwait opened and voters rushed in to elect one of the Middle East’s most robust parliaments.

content: It’s hard enough buying a first home these days. Who on Earth is out there buying a second one? The wealthy, mostly: In 2023, sales of luxury second homes increased in many U.S. markets.

title: As Heartbeat Opera Reaches a Milestone, So Does Its Musical Leader
description: Dan Schlosberg, who for 10 years has adapted opera classics for the company, has written its first world premiere.
content: For the last decade, Heartbeat Opera has treated the classics like rough drafts: The scores of “Carmen” and “Madama Butterfly,” “Fidelio” and “Der Freischütz” have been starting points for something fresh, urgent and immediate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Senison
title: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Brooklyn
description: This week’s properties are on Central Park West, in the financial district and in Park Slope.
content: A two-bedroom, two-bath, 1,400-square-foot apartment with marble countertops, a dining nook, a large primary suite, 11-foot ceilings, ample closets, a washer/dryer and window-unit air-conditioning, on the 13th floor of a 23-story prewar doorman building with a live-in super, shared laundry and shared storage. Simona Stanica and Harry Triantis, Douglas Elliman, 917-623-8326; elliman.com

description: More than three years after the attack on Congress, a Republican subcommittee chairman offered a series of baseless and disproved claims about it, reflecting an effort on the right to falsify what occurred.
content: Even by a conspiracy theorist’s standards, the wild claims made by Representative Clay Higgins, Republican of Louisiana, stand out.

author: By Michelle Goldberg and Michael Schmelling
title: Terrified Parents, New Age Health Nuts, MAGA Exiles. Meet the R.F.K. Jr. Faithful.
description: Trump voters are picking up on his mix of New Age individualism, paranoia and intense nostalgia for the America of the 1960s.
content: Chris Inclan, an alcohol and drug counselor from Sonoma, Calif., voted for the Green Party candidate Jill Stein in 2016. In 2020 he backed Andrew Yang in the Democratic primary and cast a ballot for Donald Trump in the general election. Joe Biden, he said, was “so ingrained in the establishment and politics as usual,” while Trump “went against the grain on a lot of issues,” including wars and government regulation. But Inclan, a big bearded 39-year-old with tattoos on his hands, doesn’t want to have to make that choice again, which is why he’s now enthusiastically supporting Robert F. Kennedy Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Denmark Closes Shipping Lane Over Risk of Accidental Missile Launch
description: The military said the missile malfunctioned during a test aboard a warship, and there was a possibility it could fly a short distance, but no risk of the warhead exploding.
content: Denmark halted traffic in a busy shipping lane and closed the airspace above it on Thursday, warning of a possible accidental missile launch and falling debris.

title: John Sinclair, 82, Dies; Counterculture Activist Who Led a ‘Guitar Army’
description: His imprisonment for a minor marijuana offense became a cause célèbre. He was released after John Lennon and Yoko Ono sang about him at a protest rally.
content: John Sinclair, a counterculture activist whose nearly 10-year prison sentence for sharing joints with an undercover police officer was cut short after John Lennon and Yoko Ono sang about his plight at a protest rally, died on Tuesday in Detroit. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘Chicken for Linda!’ Review: A Comedy That Cooks
description: In this madcap film, a mother’s apology leads to a delightful misadventure that begins with mourning and ends with a father’s favorite recipe.
content: In the animated French feature “Chicken for Linda!,” directed by Chiara Malta and Sébastien Laudenbach, a mother accuses her young daughter of stealing a ring of great and mournful value. When the mother, Paulette (voiced by Clotilde Hesme), discovers her error, she promises to do whatever Linda (Mélinée Leclerc) wishes by way of apology. Linda was an infant when her father died, so she asks her culinarily challenged mother to cook her father’s go-to dish: chicken and peppers.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Around Camelback Ranch, the Dodgers’ spring training home in Phoenix, fans of all backgrounds were wearing Ohtani jerseys and many spoke Japanese and Spanish.

title: ‘Kim’s Video’ Review: Following the Tapes to Italy
description: This documentary details how the coolest video collection in downtown New York ended up in a small Italian town.
content: Longtime New Yorkers of bohemian bent may be intrigued by the prospect of a documentary about Kim’s Video, the downtown rental outlet, retailer and shambolic hangout that shut its doors, as video stores tended to do, in 2014. Its title notwithstanding, “Kim’s Video,” co-directed by David Redmon and Ashley Sabin and narrated by Redmon, is less a retail history than a shaggy dog story. One that actually appears to be true. Go in knowing that and you might get a kick out of it.

author: By Tressie McMillan Cottom
title: Beyoncé Asks, and Answers, a Crucial Question in Her Latest Album
description: Beyoncé singing country music in this political climate was always going to cause a stir.
content: Beyoncé released a genre-bending country album, “Cowboy Carter,” last week. After listening to it in all the requisite settings — on a walk, in a car and on a plane — I finally understand what Beyoncé, a notoriously enigmatic pop star, wants to say to the world. She wants to be more than popular. She wants to be legendary. But first, she isn’t through taking everyone who has doubted her to the woodshed.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Reworked Italian Jerseys That Celebrate Soccer Style
description: Plus: a Nancy Brooks Brody exhibition, a Nile sailboat charter and more recommendations from T Magazine.
content: I’m a big double cleanser, sometimes even a triple cleanser. Step one is usually Biologique Recherche Eau Micellaire Biosensible, followed by Lait Dermo-S. At night, I’ll use Vintner’s Daughter Active Renewal Cleanser with cold water. I’m a big fan of Clean Skin Club towels in XL. I’m prone to acne and hyperpigmentation, and those towels really changed my skin. I use Tower 28’s SOS Rescue Spray to prevent transdermal water loss. Then I do three big droppers of Dr. Barbara Sturm’s Hyaluronic Serum, followed by Paula’s Choice Discoloration Repair Serum and Biologique Recherche Crème Dermopurifiante. I use Supergoop’s Unseen Sunscreen to lock everything in. Every evening, I cleanse and do my Dr. Dennis Gross Spectralite FaceWare Pro LED mask. I use my hyaluronic serum and, after a few minutes, apply a Tretinoin Cream USP 0.1% — my skin responds well to the constant turnover. I’ll follow with my Biologique Recherche Crème Dermopurifiante and Prequel’s Skin Utility Ointment as an occlusive layer. As needed, I use Cosmelan 2 Maintenance Cream for a spot treatment and Biologique Recherche Masque Visolastine+ as a hydrating mask. SK-II Treatment Masks are just good to have in the fridge. I’m a devotee at the temple of Vanessa Lee from the med spa the Things We Do. I did a Cosmelan peel last winter and it took away 80 to 90 percent of my hyperpigmentation. I also love the High Frequency Wand; when I have little breakouts, I’ll use that to help.

title: How an Editors’ Note Fueled Another Kate Conspiracy Theory
description: A routine Getty Images caption beside the Princess of Wales’s cancer announcement has fanned disinformation about her. Researchers say there is no evidence that the video is fake.
content: When Catherine, Princess of Wales, announced last month that she had been diagnosed with cancer, it seemed to quell the rumors that had swirled over her stepping back from public life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Plan to Stash Pollution Beneath the Sea Could Save Money and Jobs
description: The Italian energy giant Eni sees future profits from collecting carbon dioxide and pumping it into natural gas fields that have been exhausted.
content: Renowned for ancient churches and the tomb of Dante, the 14th-century poet, the city of Ravenna and its environs along Italy’s Adriatic coast are also home to old-line industries like steel and fertilizer. The manufacturing plants are of little interest to the many tourists who help sustain the area’s economy, but these sites employ tens of thousands of people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: A.I. Is Spying on the Food We Throw Away
description: Artificial intelligence is peering into restaurant garbage pails and crunching grocery-store data to try to figure out how to send less uneaten food into dumpsters.
content: A hotel chain installs a camera in its trash bins to spy on what guests are tossing. Turns out its breakfast croissants are too big. Many are going to waste — along with profits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: ‘Little Women’ and the Art of Breaking Grammatical Rules
description: In an evolving language, it ain’t always clear — or important — what’s correct.
content: A few weeks ago I wrote on the grand old rule about not ending sentences with prepositions, which is, quite simply, a long-lived hoax we’d best relegate to history. In that light, I’d like to dismantle the powerful but hopeless idea that language is something to be judged rather than observed. It can be hard to process, within the bounds of our lifetimes, the randomness of our take on what “proper” language is.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: The Buzz on Boat Shoes
description: The category of footwear created when Franklin D. Roosevelt was president is being reinterpreted and rediscovered.
content: Sometimes fashion just seems like “Groundhog Day” with better outfits. Designers vanish only to reappear suddenly (looking at you, Alessandro Michele.) Trends sputter out and abruptly are back. Skinny jeans were cool until everyone was wearing oversize drop-crotch khakis — everyone, that is, except that cadre of teen style-setters intent on bringing back 2000s-era jeggings so bad they’re good.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Baumgaertner
title: Judge Orders Timely Housing for Migrant Children Waiting at Border
description: The decision established that minors at open-air sites were in legal custody of the Department of Homeland Security and thus must receive safe shelter, even if they had not yet been formally processed.
content: The federal government is required to “expeditiously” house migrant children who cross into the United States unlawfully, rather than allow them to remain in unsafe open-air sites along the border, a Federal District Court judge ruled Wednesday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: R.F.K. Jr.’s Campaign Expressed Sympathy for Jan. 6 Rioters, Then Retracted It
description: In an email urging the United States to drop espionage charges against Julian Assange, the Kennedy campaign grouped the WikiLeaks founder with Edward Snowden and “J6 activists” in a D.C. jail.
content: The presidential campaign of Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the vaccine skeptic running as an independent candidate, said in an email on Thursday that rioters charged with crimes in connection with the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol and held in a Washington jail had been “stripped of their constitutional liberties.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni
title: Global Forest Loss Remains High, Despite Recent Progress
description: Wildfires and agricultural expansion offset big gains in protecting tropical forests last year.
content: Despite major progress in protecting vast tracts of rainforest, the world failed again last year to significantly slow the pace of global forest destruction, according to a report issued on Thursday. Record wildfires in Canada and expanding agriculture elsewhere offset big gains in forest protection in Brazil and Colombia, the report found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Coastal Retreat
description: Kevin Curry makes a delicious solo crossword debut in The New York Times.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin and Lauren Hirsch
title: A Looming Question for Paramount’s Board: How to Navigate Shari Redstone
description: The board of directors has to walk a fine line, looking out for investors without running afoul of Ms. Redstone, the company’s most influential shareholder.
content: Shari Redstone won control over her media empire in 2018 after a hard-fought struggle with CBS. In the years since, she held off on selling the family business, merging Viacom and CBS to put iconic franchises like “60 Minutes” and “Top Gun” under one roof.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fred A. Bernstein
title: Gaetano Pesce, Designer Who Broke the Rules, Is Dead at 84
description: He brought surrealism, and politics, into the design world, disdaining conformity and right angles. “He was an enemy of the grid.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien and Reid J. Epstein
title: No Labels Abandons Effort to Field a Presidential Candidate
description: The centrist group laid out grand ambitions of running a third-party candidate in a Biden-Trump contest, but the most prominent figures it courted all said no.
content: The centrist group No Labels has abandoned its plans to run a presidential ticket in the 2024 election, having failed to recruit a candidate, its leader, Nancy Jacobson, said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Goodall and Vishakha Darbha
title: Corporate America: Employees Need Stability, Not Constant Change
description: Silicon Valley was all about disruption. Turns out, that’s not all workers need.
content: It’s been a brutal year for Silicon Valley, with dozens of mass layoffs and company reorganizations. Ashley Goodall, a former tech executive and the author of the forthcoming book, “The Problem with Change,” believes that this is a byproduct of C.E.O.s trying to please shareholders and that we have corporate success all wrong. In this audio essay, he argues that change and disruption are not always good and that if executives want better work environments, they should prioritize their employees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Blatt
title: Eclipse’s Path Is Also Leaving a Trail of High Hotel Prices
description: One Super 8 in Illinois advertised $949 a night. Its normal rate is $95.
content: The solar eclipse that will cast a visible shadow across the United States on Monday is already leaving an obvious mark on hotel prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Caitlin O'Hara
title: Inside a G.O.P. Plan to Encourage Early Voting Despite Trump’s Attacks
description: Donald Trump’s falsehoods about mail voting have created a strategic disadvantage for Republicans, who must rely on Election Day turnout. The group Turning Point Action has a $100 million plan to change voters’ habits.
content: Inside a sprawling compound in Phoenix, leaders of the influential conservative group Turning Point Action were hatching plans to fix what they see as a mortal threat to the Republican Party: its voters’ avoidance of early voting, especially by mail, since the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Review: Turning Dancers Into Aliens One Step at a Time
description: Under the artistic leadership of Emily Molnar, Nederlands Dans Theater returned to New York City Center with a less than stellar triple bill.
content: Emily Molnar, the artistic director of Nederlands Dans Theater, is committed to giving her dancers, as she has said, “creative agency and a greater sense of belonging.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag
title: On the Hunt, a Real Estate Reporter Strikes Gold
description: A man’s bizarre scheme to take over a hotel had the makings of an only-in-New-York story.
content: I first heard of Mickey Barreto a few hours after he was arrested early on Valentine’s Day this year. He had been arraigned in a Manhattan court in what prosecutors said was a blatant, persistent scheme to take ownership of the once-grand New Yorker Hotel in Midtown. Mr. Barreto’s bizarre takeover bid was based on a one-night stay he booked more than five years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson
title: Music Teacher Is Charged With Taking Teenagers on Trips to Abuse Them
description: Paul Geer taught for decades at the Family Foundation School, a rural reform academy where he abused students, an indictment states.
content: The music teacher’s classes at the strict, no-nonsense reform school in the woods of upstate New York would seem to be a teenager’s respite amid all the rules, a place for expression and discovery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: World Central Kitchen Demands an Independent Investigation Into Israeli Strike
description: The Israeli military, which has accepted responsibility for the strike, has started looking into the killings of seven aid workers. But the disaster relief organization said that was not enough.
content: World Central Kitchen on Thursday called for an independent investigation into the killing by Israeli forces of seven of its staff members this week as they worked to deliver aid in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Sloat
title: Amid Recalls, Are Eye Drops Safe to Use?
description: Here’s why some products have been pulled from store shelves, and what to know to protect your eyes.
content: Dozens of eye drops and ointments have been pulled from store shelves after a wave of recalls in 2023 and 2024, raising concerns about whether products used to relieve dry or irritated eyes are safe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Kate Shindle on Why She’s Stepping Down as Actors’ Equity President
description: After nine years in the role, she has decided not to seek re-election in May. Her departure comes amid significant turnover in the theater industry.
content: Kate Shindle, who has served as president of Actors’ Equity Association for nine years, is stepping down after a tenure dominated by the coronavirus pandemic that for a time idled all of the labor union’s members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brandon Yu
title: ‘The First Omen’ Review: The Days Before Damien
description: A prequel to the original franchise, this debut feature from Arkasha Stevenson is a thrilling mash-up of horror tropes that gives the story new life.
content: If the “Omen” franchise left us with memorable tropes — the boy Antichrist, lurking among us; those dreaded three repeated numbers — the content of the movies themselves did little else. The original horror trilogy, kicked off by “The Omen” in 1976, never had the sticking power of other classics in popular consciousness, and a 2006 revamp came and went. What could another attempt, this time a prequel to a middling franchise, really offer?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley, Meaghan Tobin, Siyi Zhao and Lam Yik Fei
title: Why Taiwan Was So Prepared for a Powerful Earthquake
description: Decades of learning from disasters, tightening building codes and increasing public awareness may have helped its people better weather strong quakes.
content: When the largest earthquake in Taiwan in half a century struck off its east coast, the buildings in the closest city, Hualien, swayed and rocked. As more than 300 aftershocks rocked the island over the next 24 hours to Thursday morning, the buildings shook again and again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: From One Leaning Tower to Another, Tips to Stop the Tilt
description: Bologna is looking to Pisa, home of the most famous leaning tower, for help keeping its own tipping tower upright.
content: Leaning for centuries at a worrisome tilt, the Garisenda Tower in Bologna has endured insults and trauma. Dickens called it “sufficiently unsightly,” if extraordinary, while Goethe said it was “a spectacle that disgusts.” And then there were the earthquakes, the Allied bombing raids of the city during World War II and urbanization that doomed other towers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Lawyers Call on U.K. Government to End Arms Sales to Israel
description: The government is coming under more pressure to suspend arms sales to Israel after the strike on a convoy in Gaza that killed seven aid workers, including three Britons.
content: The British government is coming under escalating pressure to suspend arms sales to Israel after the strike on a convoy in Gaza that killed seven aid workers, including three Britons. More than 600 lawyers and retired judges sent a letter to the government, arguing that the sales violated international law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Hospital at Center of Alabama Embryo Ruling Is Ending I.V.F. Services
description: The hospital cited a “lack of clarity” in recent state legislation meant to shield I.V.F. providers as a factor in its decision. A separate fertility clinic at the site said it would relocate.
content: A Mobile, Ala., hospital at the center of a State Supreme Court ruling that found that frozen embryos could be considered children said on Wednesday that it would no longer provide in vitro fertilization lab services after this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Has Your Relationship to School Attendance Changed Since the Pandemic?
description: School absences have exploded across the United States. What do you make of this trend?
content: Take a look at the graph above. It shows rates of chronic absence in the United States since 2016. What do you notice? What do you wonder? What story does it tell about the state of education today? What headline would you write to capture the graph’s main idea?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: How to Make Fear Your Friend
description: A winning essay by Zoe Brown, age 14.
content: This essay, by Zoe Brown, 14, of Bend, Ore., is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s new “How To” Informational Writing Contest for Teenagers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Trains Are Cleaner Than Planes, Right?
description: The surprising carbon footprint of an Amtrak trip across America.
content: Recently, I did something I’ve long dreamed of. I took the train across America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Environmental Protection Agency Gives $20 Billion in ‘Green Bank’ Grants
description: The E.P.A. said the fund will spur a clean energy transition in overlooked communities. Republicans called it a “greendoggle.”
content: When Marcus Jones and his business partner, Akunna Olumba, set out to open a pizzeria in Detroit, they spoke with banks about their green vision: solar panels on the roof, an energy-efficient tankless water heater and a rooftop system to capture storm water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: Hochul Orders M.T.A. to Stop Pressuring Marathon to Pay for Lost Tolls
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority wanted the New York City Marathon to pay $750,000 to make up for toll revenue lost when the Verrazzano-Narrows Bridge was closed.
content: Gov. Kathy Hochul on Thursday said that she had ordered the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to drop its effort to charge the New York City Marathon roughly $750,000 for its use of the Verrazzano-Narrows Bridge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon, Caitlin O'Keefe and Anna Foley
title: Biden Is Winning the Money Race. Does It Matter?
description: Inside the very expensive business of running for president.
content: Last week, President Biden, flanked by former Presidents Barack Obama and Bill Clinton, came to Radio City Music Hall for what Mr. Biden’s campaign called “the most successful political fund-raiser in American history.” The three Democratic presidents, alongside celebrities like Stephen Colbert, Mindy Kaling, Lizzo and Queen Latifah, spoke to an audience of 5,000 donors. According to the Biden campaign, the event brought in more than $25 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Kugel
title: Help! Japan Airlines Downgraded Us From First Class and Skimped on the Refund.
description: A couple is bumped from ultraluxury to semi-luxury on a trans-Pacific flight and receives what they feel is only a pittance in compensation.
content: Last year, my husband and I splurged on round-trip first-class tickets on Japan Airlines from San Francisco to Tokyo for $13,474 each. We reserved them in February for an October flight through American Express Travel. On the same day, I also bought business class tickets for a couple who was traveling with us at $8,429 apiece. In September, Amex notified me that we had been downgraded to business class for the return flight. JAL’s conditions state that we would receive “the difference between the normal fare amount of original class of service and for the normal fare of lower class of service.” To me that means that since the difference between our first class seats and our friends’ business seats was $5,045 each, we should be refunded about half of that — around $2,522 per person — for the second leg. But we got only $941 each. I contested this with Amex Travel, but they rejected our claim. Can you help? Teri, San Francisco
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simran Hans
title: What to Know About ‘Scoop’ and Prince Andrew’s Explosive TV Interview
description: A new Netflix film dramatizes the 2019 BBC conversation that led to the royal stepping back from public life.
content: When Prince Andrew, Queen Elizabeth II’s second son, agreed to be interviewed on the BBC in November 2019, he likely didn’t expect it would one day inspire a feature film. But “Scoop,” which comes to Netflix on Friday, follows a TV musical and a documentary in depicting the 58-minute interview and its fallout. (Amazon is also producing an upcoming limited series.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Knight
title: Progressive Candidate Could Upend the San Francisco Mayor’s Race
description: The contest has been dominated by Mayor London Breed and her moderate challengers. Supervisor Aaron Peskin seeks to change that.
content: San Francisco residents have repeatedly told pollsters they don’t support Mayor London Breed. But until now, every one of her challengers in the November election has sounded a lot like her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: A.L.S. Drug Relyvrio Will Be Taken Off the Market, Its Maker Says
description: Results of a large clinical trial found the treatment did not work any better than a placebo.
content: The maker of the newest treatment approved for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis said Thursday that it would withdraw the drug from the market because a large clinical trial did not produce evidence that the treatment worked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: California Congressional Primary Has a Rare Tie for a Runoff Spot
description: Never before has California’s primary system resulted in a three-way runoff for a congressional seat.
content: California’s primary system — in which the top two vote-getters, regardless of party, advance to the general election — has seeded plenty of unusual showdowns since it was established a little more than a decade ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter
title: When the Rubin Museum Was Divine
description: The Rubin will be “reimagined” as a global museum, but our critic says its charismatic presence will be only a troubling memory.
content: A brick-and-mortar presence can be, often is, a crucial part of an art museum’s allure. The Guggenheim’s mother ship interior is such a thrill that it prepares you to love whatever’s on view. The interiors of the Frick and the Morgan are intimate enough to make you feel proprietarily, and fabulously, at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Kaufman
title: Do You Need a Home Watcher? Here’s What One Could Do for You.
description: Hiring a local to keep an eye on your weekend house can give you peace of mind and keep small problems from becoming big headaches.
content: Leslie Young has a message for new second-home owners: That house of yours isn’t going to look after itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: For Sale: One Huge Drawing, Maybe by Michelangelo
description: Former owners of the Renaissance artist’s villa want to sell a sketch once on a kitchen wall. But scholars are divided over whether Michelangelo actually drew it.
content: For half a century, the Sernesi family lived in a storied villa overlooking Florence, in which the Renaissance artist Michelangelo was raised and later owned. The property came with several buildings, an orchard and a drawing of a muscular male nude etched on the wall of a former kitchen. Tradition has it that the work was drawn by a young Michelangelo, though scholars are not as sure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: Septic Installer Is Sentenced to 7 Years for Urging Jan. 6 Mob With Megaphone
description: Taylor James Johnatakis, 40, coordinated rioters to rush a police barricade at the Southwest stairs to the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6.
content: A Washington State man has been sentenced to more than seven years in prison for his role in the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol, where prosecutors said he used a megaphone to urge other rioters to barge through a police line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: TikTok Turns to Nuns, Veterans and Ranchers in Marketing Blitz
description: The video app is spending millions on ads as Congress considers a bill that could lead to a U.S. ban.
content: In a TV commercial, Sister Monica Clare, a nun in northern New Jersey, walks through a church that’s bathed in sunlight and sits in a pew, crossing herself. Her message: TikTok is a force for good.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: How to Be a Kid Forever
description: A winning essay by Raniya Chowdhury, age 17.
content: This essay, by Raniya Chowdhury, 17, of Mississauga, Ontario, is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s new “How To” Informational Writing Contest for Teenagers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: If You Give a Kid a Notebook, He’s Going to Ask for Time to Write
description: John Schu is a best-selling author, a children’s librarian and a tireless evangelist for the power of a blank page.
content: When John Schu was admitted to Linden Oaks Hospital in Naperville, Ill., as a teenager, the staff gave him a gray notebook and encouraged him to write in it every day. “I would write a lot in the beginning, but I refused to share anything,” Schu said in a phone interview. “I would do some of the assignments, but I would always say, ‘Nobody can read it.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Guerrero
title: Celebrating History With 200,000 Tulips
description: Tulip Day is coming, as part of an initiative by the Netherlands Consulate General and other groups to mark the 400th anniversary of Dutch settlers’ arrival in what is now New York.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today we’ll look at why truckloads of tulips are coming to Union Square this weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘Música’ Review: What He Hears Is What We Get
description: Rudy Mancuso stars in and directs an inventive debut feature about a man with synesthesia who tries to manage his complicated life and relationships.
content: The artist Rudy Mancuso has a prolific career that’s hard to define. He sings, shoots puppet skits and films wistful live action shorts set to his own piano tunes. Mancuso uploads most of his output online; however, he opened for Justin Bieber in Brazil, where he once lived. “Música,” Mancuso’s phenomenal feature debut, is a comic trip inside a mind that’s forever feverishly creating — even against his will. In the first scene, Rudy (Mancuso), his semi-autobiographical lead, gets dumped at a diner because his synesthesia won’t allow him to focus on a serious talk about the future. His brain can’t ignore a knife chopping, a broom sweeping, a spatula clanking. The percussion swells, the clatter harmonizes and his romance collapses, leaving Rudy alone in his bedroom with a lamp attached to — oh dear — a Clapper.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: The Takeaways From Disney’s Board Fight with Nelson Peltz
description: New voting rules made for sharper attacks, while a bold defense kept the activist investor at bay. But pressure remains on the company’s chief, Bob Iger.
content: It’s over. Disney fended off the activist investor Nelson Peltz for the second time in two years, as its shareholders rejected his effort to win two seats on its board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gregory Nolan
title: A Reversal Cannot Undo the Damage Caused by This Voting Fraud Case
description: What happened to Crystal Mason in Texas could have broader consequences in chilling people’s willingness to exercise their right to vote.
content: When a Texas appeals court reversed itself last week and acquitted Crystal Mason, a mother of three, in a voting fraud case, it ended almost a decade in which Ms. Mason lived in fear of being torn away from her family and imprisoned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Bayrakdarian
title: Do You Have Experience With Gun Violence? Tell Us About It.
description: Headway wants to hear from people affected by gun violence and those working to end it.
content: As of the beginning of the month, there had been 95 mass shootings in the United States in 2024, according to the Gun Violence Archive, or roughly a mass shooting every day of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Monkey Man’ Review: Vengeance Is His
description: Dev Patel stars as Kid, a human punching bag who comes up with a plan to avenge a past wrong. The hits keep coming and the hero keeps taking them in this rapid-fire film.
content: The thriller “Monkey Man” opens on a tender scene and a nod to the power of storytelling, only to quickly get down to down-and-dirty, action-movie business with a flurry of hard blows and faster edits. For the next two frenetic hours, it repeatedly cuts back to the past — where a mother and child happily lived once upon a bucolic time — before returning to the grubby, raw-knuckle present. There, the hits keep coming and the hero keeps taking them, again and again, in a movie that tries so hard to keep you entertained, it ends up exhausting you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Curtis, Wendy Dorr, Jancee Dunn and Diane Wong
title: Julia Louis-Dreyfus Wants You to Listen to Older Women
description: The actress reflects on Season 2 of “Wiser Than Me.”
content: Our Well columnist, Jancee Dunn, talks with the actress Julia Louis-Dreyfus about her podcast “Wiser Than Me,” which just started its second season. Louis-Dreyfus discusses why putting older women in the spotlight is powerful, how the show has affected her own thoughts about aging, and how being comfortable in your own skin makes for some refreshing real talk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devorah Lev-Tov
title: When You Share an Anniversary With an Eclipse
description: A number of couples are choosing to marry during the upcoming total solar eclipse. Several cities in the path of totality are holding mass weddings.
content: When Zach Horrall, a social media specialist at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, and Corlan McCollum, a children’s librarian, got engaged two years ago, they wanted to connect their wedding to a larger event. At first, they considered Halloween, but when they realized Indianapolis was in the path of totality for the April 8, 2024, solar eclipse, they changed course.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Video Game Reviews of 2024
description: New York Times critics are examining new horror games and point-and-click adventures, along with remakes of classic titles.
content: Playing every video game that is released would be an incredibly time-consuming project. To help you sort through the options (and maybe your backlog), here is an alphabetical list of the games that New York Times critics have written about in 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Biden Threatens to Condition Israel Aid
description: Also, ocean temperatures signal a daunting hurricane season. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
content: During a tense 30-minute call today with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, President Biden threatened to condition future American support for Israel on whether it improves its treatment of civilians in Gaza. Biden called the humanitarian situation in the enclave “unacceptable,” and insisted to Netanyahu that he quickly put in place specific protections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikita Richardson
title: These Brooklyn Restaurateurs Are Crossing the East River
description: Big names in Brooklyn are heading to Manhattan.
content: Sometimes I receive emails from readers saying that I recommend too many Brooklyn restaurants. Though I disagree, I will admit: That’s where I’ve lived since arriving in New York City, so I think it’s a very special place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Florida Court Rulings Pose Risks for House Republicans on Abortion
description: The twin decisions have all but guaranteed that voters will have the issue on their minds in November, bringing potential risks for two anti-abortion Republicans in the state whose districts aren’t solidly red.
content: Representative Anna Paulina Luna, a hard-right Republican from Florida, has proudly described herself as a “pro-life extremist.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Friday Briefing: Six Months of the Israel-Hamas War
description: Also, the rise of “carefluencers.”
content: Sunday marks six months since the Oct. 7 attacks that started Israel’s war against Hamas. More than 32,000 Palestinians have died, people are desperate for aid and dozens of Israeli hostages are still being held in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: In a Box
description: What do you think this image is communicating?
content: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: Biden and Netanyahu speak as a senior official says the president’s anger with Israel has hit a peak.
description: President Biden spoke with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Thursday, three days after international aid workers were killed in an Israeli strike, as senior American officials said his frustration over Israel’s actions in Gaza was coming to a head.
content: President Biden spoke with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Thursday, three days after international aid workers were killed in an Israeli strike, as senior American officials said his frustration over Israel’s actions in Gaza was coming to a head.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova and Sasha Arutyunova
title: She Slept With a Violin on Her Pillow. Her Dreams Came True in Italy.
description: As a teenager in South Korea, Ayoung An decided to become a violin maker. Her journey eventually took her to Cremona, Italy, a famed hub for masters like Antonio Stradivari.
content: When Ayoung An was 8, her parents bought her a violin. She slept with the instrument on the pillow next to her every night.

title: How to Revive a Burned Forest? Rebuild the Tree Supply Chain
description: As forests succumb to ever-fiercer wildfires, the federal government and some adventurous private companies are trying to resuscitate an industry.

title: Here’s How Congress Can Use Leverage on Weapons Sales to Prod Biden on Israel
description: Congress has oversight over American weapons sales to allies. Some Democrats say lawmakers should try to delay or even block them until Israel agrees to conditions on its offensive in Gaza.
content: Democrats in Congress, increasingly concerned about how Israel is waging war in Gaza, are weighing whether to use their leverage over weapons sales to register objections to the civilian death toll and ratchet up pressure on President Biden to place conditions on American backing for the military offensive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: ‘The Old Oak’ Review: The Audacity of Hope
description: A family of Syrian refugees connects with a once-thriving mining town in Ken Loach’s moving drama.
content: “The Old Oak” is named for the pub where much of its action happens — an old drinking hole in a village outside of Durham, England, that’s seen better days. Its back room, once a gathering place for the miners and their families who populated the town a generation ago, has been locked up for many years, fallen to disuse. Its walls are still hung with photographs of those miners taken during the lengthy strike of 1984-1985, a labor effort that ended without the resolution the miners sought and with weakened trade unions. But during the action, the village marched in solidarity — at least for a while — and came together to share meals in that back room, to support one another, a point of pride for the men who were children back then.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: Jonathan Levin, Dean of Business School, Is Stanford’s New President
description: Dr. Levin faces the challenge of guiding the university through politically fraught times.
content: Stanford University’s next president will be Jonathan Levin, an economist who currently serves as dean of the graduate business school and whose association with the university dates back to his undergraduate days in the 1990s.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 7 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: Where are all the books about work? That question lands in our inbox from time to time, and no wonder: In terms of hours and paychecks and the sense of identity they impart, jobs are a consuming part of our lives that authors do indeed too often neglect. So this week we recommend three books that put the world of paid labor front and center: Adelle Waldman’s novel “Help Wanted” is set in a suburban box store, Hamilton Nolan’s “The Hammer” assesses the current state of union organizing, and Jane Kamensky’s “Candida Royalle and the Sexual Revolution” takes the measure of a proto-girlboss who went from starring in pornographic movies to launching her own production company with a feminist slant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Ripley’ Review: The Con Man Gets the Art House Treatment
description: Andrew Scott stars in a Netflix series that looks like what you might get if Antonioni or Resnais had directed a season of “The White Lotus.”
content: Patricia Highsmith’s 1955 novel “The Talented Mr. Ripley” sets its dark action in a succession of colorful Italian locales: the Amalfi coast, San Remo, Rome, Palermo, Venice. Movies based on the book, like René Clément’s “Plein Soleil” (released in the United States as “Purple Noon”) and Anthony Minghella’s “The Talented Mr. Ripley,” have taken the opportunity Highsmith gave them to capitalize on sun and scenery. The audience gets its brutal murders and brazen deceit wrapped in bright visual pleasure.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Mayor Eric Adams keeps finding eye-catching ways to seize the spotlight on the issue of public safety, even when the narrative turns against him.

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Coup de Chance’ Review: Woody Allen’s Usual With a French Twist
description: Despite its Parisian setting, the setup is familiar from any of Allen’s New York movies: An act of infidelity presents a dilemma. Some of the jokes are funny.
content: “Coup de Chance,” the latest from Woody Allen, looks and plays like many of his recent movies, only better; it sounds like them, too, except that it’s in French. Set entirely in France, it features well-heeled, loquacious narcissists who circle one another in a comic-dramatic story that touches on existential worries and folds in lightly jaundiced observations about life. There are pretty people and handsome homes, repressed lives and unleashed desires, the usual. As is often the case in Allen’s movies, there’s also an act of infidelity, which presents a dilemma, if not an especially torturous one. The jokes are fairly muted; some are funny.
source.name: The New York Times

content: The exposés that brought public attention to Watergate, the predations of Harvey Weinstein and the abuse tolerated by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston have all been the subjects of movies. The drama revolved, in part, around the difficulty of getting people to talk.

content: For decades, Sammy’s Tap & Grill, a sports bar for fans of North Carolina State University, had a glaring problem: The school’s basketball teams did not win all that much. David Harris, one of the owners, would concoct creative specials in hopes of drawing customers on game days, but it didn’t matter. Few ever came.

author: By Arthur Lubow
title: Welcoming Underexposed Black Photographers Into the Canon
description: The Vision & Justice publishing initiative hopes to build a richer, more racially inclusive history of photography.
content: Elegant in a burnt-orange linen dress and wearing necklaces of her own design, Coreen Simpson, 82, said that because she was raised in foster homes, “I have always felt like an outsider — which is a good thing for a photographer.” But as a Black artist of an older generation, she was made to feel like an outsider in other ways, too. “I’ve wanted my own book for a long time,” she said, during an interview in her Brooklyn apartment. “I just wanted a serious book on my work, because I think I deserve it, to tell you the truth.” Thanks to the Vision & Justice project, that deficit is about to be corrected.

content: On April 8, millions of people will look toward the sky for the total solar eclipse, the first to be visible in North America since 2017. The moon will cross directly in front of the sun, blocking light and casting a shadow on Earth as it makes its journey north from Mexico, over the United States and into Canada. For the more than 30 million people who live inside the path of totality — and the many more who are traveling to optimal viewing spots — daylight will momentarily disappear. In other areas, it will dim.
